title: Iain Macwhirter  Get over it - cis women are just on the wrong side of history
story: This, apparently, is to educate heteronormative women about their ldquoprivilege ndash the fact that they can use the toilets, sorry ldquowashrooms, of their choice and access healthcare. Irsquom not sure who exactly has been preventing transgender women using public conveniences. So far as I know, you donrsquot have to show a birth certicate, or undergo a medical exam to have a pee. But what do I know as a pale, stale male.What I do know is that ldquocis-gender is an ugly neologism which many women find offensive. They are content with their present sexual terminology. ldquoCis is in the same linguistic ballpark as ldquoTERF ndash trans exclusionary radical feminist, which is a term of abuse used against women who believe persons with penises are, er, male. I should be careful here because a number of TERFS have been banned from social media for saying that a person with a penis is a man. So I wonrsquot say that.Instead, letrsquos just take it as read that in future we are going to have to accept that the concept of sexual dferentiation with which we have been living for thousands of years is finally being exposed as a malign transphobic hood. At any rate, the Scottish Government appears determined to press ahead with reform of the Gender Recognition Act, which will allow trans people to assign themselves legally and biologically female. Hitherto, trans people have had to undergo medical examination and get a diagnosis of ldquogender dysphoria. No more. From now on, anyone can change their birth certicate to whatever they wish.Earlier this month, Holyroodrsquos culture committee warned that ending binary ldquoMale or Female questions in the Scottish census will render much of the results meaningless and, willy nilly, import an unscientic definition of sex into the law. But the Scottish Government is not listening. Nicola Sturgeon told a UN equalities conference last week that the concerns of feminists about the GRA are ldquomisplaced.Women ndash sorry, ldquomenstruators ndash who say that self-ID erases their sexual identity will be told: just get over it. They can complain that ldquosex is a protected characteristic under the  Equalities Act, and that women therefore have a right to their own unique spaces. But now that men can actually become women under the law, this right will be impossible to articulate. Trans women with male anatomy will be entitled to enter womenrsquos changing rooms, girl guide troops or womenrsquos prisons. Women who complain will be guilty of transphobia, and are likely to be visited by the police recording a ldquohate incident.Now, I have nothing against adults changing their gender, or identying as women, queer, non-binary, intersex or whatever. It seems to be reinforcing outmoded concepts of gender to suggest that, because someone wants to wear dresses, play with dolls and put on makeup, they must have a lady brain in a male body. I thought we had left pink-for-girls gender stereotyping behind. But never mind. No-one wishes trans people any ill ndash certainly not me. But now that we are abandoning the very biological definition of sex, there are some anomalies that need to be addressed.Last week, a British transgender man, who had IVF by sperm donation and gave birth, won a court battle to prevent his child having ldquomother on its birth certicate. It will be the first child in history to have no mother. The The AIRE Centre, a human rights charity, contested this on the grounds that it would make le dficult for the child in future, when they apply for visas or anything which enquires about family background. The Government said simply that this isnrsquot a problem. From now on, fathers can give birth ndash end of.But Irsquom not sure this is the end of the matter. Children have not been included in the gender recognition debate thus far, even though they have rights too. It could be psychologically disturbing for a child to find, one day, that its mother has decided to become its dad. That song ldquoSometimes I feel like a motherless child takes on a whole new meaning.Of course, the trans parent will still be present, but is it OK to expect a child to suddenly start calling her natural mother her father  I would have thought that a child has a continuing right to a legal motherthey were born with one. If misgendering a trans person is unacceptable, surely demothering a child should be too. This is going to be confusing to say the least.Then there is the question of sport. The controversy over athlete Caster Semenya, a woman with high testosterone, raises the question of how to regard trans womenrsquos participation in women-only sport. Athletes who have testes, and therefore posses greater body mass, muscle strength and bone density, have an unfair advantage over old-fashioned women who have genetically female bodies.Next week, the International Association of Athletics Federations will argue in a hearing in Switzerland that people like Semenya should take testosterone-suppressing drugs before competing. Not only would this drive a coach and horses through the anti-doping protocols, it surely poses problem for transgender athletes who, of course, also take drugs like testosterone to help them transition to their ldquocorrect male sex. I hope the sporting authorities can get their heads around that because I canrsquot.Yet this is a very live issue in many sports. In the US, the ban on trans women taking part in power-lting events is being lted to prevent accusations of discrimination. You might have thought that having beefy, male-bodied women participating in these contests is discriminating against women athletes. Though, of course, only transphobes would say that, so we wonrsquot go there.The logical solution to this conundrum is to end sexual segregation in sport. Andwomen who are born biologically female never win any medals, tough. Strangely, there doesnrsquot seem to be the same issue about female-bodied trans men participating in male-only sport . Irsquom sure that has nothing whatever to do with the fact that they wonrsquot win anything.So welcome to the brave new world of post-sexual dferentiation, where men become women and fathers have children. It is one of the most radical and abrupt cultural changes in human history.Women have had a pretty bad deal in previous centuries, when they were regarded often as chattels without rights. In some Muslim societies theyrsquore still second-class citizens. Now, as women are finally emerging from the shadow of patriarchy, they are being told, by men, that they no longer have exclusive rights to their sexual identity.Itrsquos a weird turn of events. It seems women are just on the wrong side of history. But somehow, I donrsquot think theyrsquoll go quietly.

title: Marianne Taylor  Last chance for Mundell to put country before party
story: The majority of these demands are perfunctory, of course, made in the knowledge and expectation that they will be ignored by the target, while playing well with the initiatorrsquos supporters.The craziness of the last few months has precipitated a flurry of genuine and warranted resignation demands, however, which under normal political circumstances would have resulted in multiple ministerial heads rolling in any other era the Prime Minister would have been forced out long ago.Marianne Taylor: BBC is better off without Neil and HumphrysAnother case in point is Scottish Secretary David Mundell, whose stubborn insistence on being ineffectual in the face of the biggest crisis this country has faced in generations is matched only by that of Jeremy Corbyn. Mr Mundellrsquos wan smiles and empty words about doing the best for Scotland as the Government he is a member of readies itself to push us off the no-deal Brexit clf, is as astonishing as it is appalling. He, too, should have gone months ago, not least over the manner in which his party has arrogantly steamrollered over the views and interests of the country he supposedly represents.Read more: Mundell should resign there is no-deal BrexitRemarkably still in post, Mr Mundell now has one last chance to make a meaningful contribution to the ridiculous and dangerous situation the Westminster parliament has created for itself. The SNP is right to call for Mr Mundell to show some mettle and make clear that he will not serve in a Government that is willing to take us out of the European Union without a deal, a situation that would put the already fragile Scottish economy on the road to ruin. As the Scottish Secretary is well aware, businesses will fail, jobs will be lost and real people will suffer the sort of real hardships that will be dficult to recover from.Marianne Taylor: BBC is better off without Neil and HumphrysSNP Westminster leader Ian Blackford has written to Mr Mundell, laying out the gravity of the situation and calling on him to back growing cross-party demands to halt the Brexit process by extending Article  and making clear to his boss, Theresa May, that he will resign unless she faces up the extremists in her party and takes no-deal off the table.At this critical juncture, the least that the people of Scotland deserve from the man who represents them at Cabinet level is honesty about where his loyalties lie: will he put country or party first  Mr Mundell, it really is that simple.Read more: Mundell should resign there is no-deal BrexitOf course, Mr Blackfordrsquos letter also highlights the bleakness of the dilemma facing the SNP. If Mrs May gets her way and Parliament is faced with a last-minute binary choice between her terrible deal - which deprives us of the key benefits being in the EU - and an even more catastrophic no-deal, it leaves the party in a dficult position. How should Nicola Sturgeon instruct her MPs to vote in this scenario  Backing Mrs Mayrsquos ldquomy way or the highway deal would be criticised by many as a U-turn of epic proportions and a sign of weakness. Not voting for it, and thus facilitating a no-deal Brexit, would likely be viewed by many voters as unforgivable, leaving the party open to allegations that this is the outcome it has been secretly hoping for all along, in order to boost support for independence.Ms Sturgeon and her colleagues will be hoping the growing number of Tory ministers and backbench MPs ndash including Cabinet secretaries Amber Rudd, Greg Clarke and David Gauke - poised to revolt against their leader should she refuse to rule out a no-deal Brexit, will come to their rescue in the frantic days and weeks to come.Marianne Taylor: BBC is better off without Neil and HumphrysThe emergence of the The Independent Groupmay also end up helping the SNPrsquos predicament, at least in the short term. Formed last week when eight MPs resigned from Labour unhappy at Mr Corbynrsquos disastrous leadership, it did not initially appear to be an important development. But when three Tory MPs also resigned and joined up, using the moment to launch a blistering attack on Mrs Mayrsquos disastrous Brexit strategy and their partyrsquos lurch to the right, it started to feel more signicant.What binds these MPs from dferent sides of the House of Commons is dismay at the drt of both parties to the extremities. And despite not being a proper party - yet - or having any actual policiesit seems many voters quite like what they see.Read more: Mundell should resign there is no-deal BrexitMomentum has grown over the weekend, with polls already putting the group on  per cent, just one behind the increasingly irrelevant Lib Dems.Many are asking whether TIG has a future. Surely, however, whatrsquos most important is the future of the country, andthis new movement serves only to facilitate the halting of Article , so that a new road out of the current mess can be found, then it will already have done more for the UK than Mr Corbyn. Or indeed Mr Mundell for that matter.

title: what-it-feels-like-to-reach-100-years-of-age
story: Itrsquos not been that easy getting here, to be honest. I just took every birthday as it came and suddenly I realised ndash Irsquom going to be ! I have the odd pain here and there, Irsquom a bit unsteady on my feet now and I got a pacemaker fitted when I was  but on the whole, Irsquom doing all right. The consultant who fitted the pacemaker saidhe could bottle my genes and sell them, he would make a fortune.My dad was in World War One, then he worked for the railways. My mum came from the north of Scotland, a wee place  miles from Elgin, called Auchenhalrig. We went there every summer for years, and I just loved it.I left school at the age of , to work in Robert Simpson and Sons, a hardware and clothing shop on Jamaica Street ndash which eventually became House of Fraser. They sent me to the tailoring room at first, but I couldnrsquot even sew on a button, so what on earth did I know about making clothes  So I became a shorthand typist then a bookkeeper, and I stayed there until I retired in , when I was . I loved every minute of it.I loved dancing, too. We didnrsquot go to the big dance halls in Glasgow, we preferred the wee local hall in Springburn, where I loved. Wersquod go on a Saturday night, maybe get a lsquowalk homersquo.That was where I met Alex. He came in with a friend, and as soon as I saw him, I thought ndash Irsquom going to get him. And I did. We got married in .I took some time off to have my daughter, June, and I went back to work when she was eight. Mothers go back to work too early nowadays, in my opinion. June was, and still is, a perfect child. She comes to visit, she cooks for me. We have Morrisons Mondays, when we go out for lunch and shopping. I donrsquot get around so well now, my balance is a bit off, so I need a wheelchair when Irsquom out. We go on holiday together too ndash we were away up north to Morayshire twice last year, which was lovely.Alex died in , after a long struggle with diabetes and heart disease. I still miss him.I spend my spare time watching sport. Irsquom a big Aberdeen fan, and used to listen to the games on the radio with my mother, Jean. Even when she went in to hospital, near the end of her le, shersquod put on the tranny and wersquod listen to the football together. The club were kind to me when I turned  in December. They sent me a special programme, with my picture in it. I also got a card from Anton du Beke, organised by my family. He said: ldquoI wish I was there to dance with you, Betty. That was lovely.And of course I got a telegram from the Queen. The South Lanarkshire Provost came to visit and we had a party. I felt like a VIP.Losing friends is the hardest thing about being . My best friend here in Lochaber Court died many years ago, and Irsquom still here.I donrsquot think therersquos a secret to growing old. Irsquove just done it my way andI could do it again, Irsquod do it all the same. Irsquove just been me.ANN FOTHERINGHAM

title: liquidators-appointed-to-hourstons-ltd-in-ayr
story: The business, which is no longer trading, will cease to exist from today and  employees will lose their jobs with immediate effect.:Fears over hundreds of Debenhams jobs in Scotland as  UK stores to closeHourstons is a well-known high street retailer in Ayr which was established  years ago and provided a broad offering of fashion, beauty, gts and furniture alongside a cafeacute.Linda Barr, Restructuring and Debt Advisory director at accountants French Duncan LLP, said: ldquoUnfortunately, this is a sign of the times and the very real changes which have occurred in the High Street."The High Street has become a much more hostile place for many traditional businesses as consumers sht their spending online leaving the centres of our towns and cities with large scale businesses suddenly missing essential customers. It is extremely dficult to turn around long-established businesses once sales start to fall and dficulties emerge.ldquoHourstons is an iconic brand in Ayrshire and its closure, and the loss of jobs, will be a dficult pill to swallow for the people and community of Ayr.Linda concluded: ldquoWe shall be selling off the assets of the business but, unfortunately, not as a going concern. The main property is currently being marketed as a development opportunity by CBRE and DM Hall and is unlikely to remain a retail site in the future.Eileen Blackburn, French Duncanrsquos Head of Restructuring and Debt Advisory, commented: ldquoHourstons battled against the changing retail environment but this is a story being told on the High Streets of many of our town and city centres as a lot of traditional retailers close because of major consumer changes.Eileen concluded: ldquoLocal councils need to look at ways to assist retailers, casual dining outlets and other stalwarts of the High Street to ensure that city centres remain attractive to consumers in the years to come.However, punitive business taxes and an inflexible approach by landlordsare leading to retail deserts in the heart of our communities.Local councils undoubtedly donrsquot want the destruction of our city centres to occur but donrsquot seem to be acting quickly enough to prevent further closures.

title: inside-diageos-edinburgh-johnnie-walker-experience-the-concept
story: The pound million Scotland-wide whisky tourism investment by the drinks giant includes roofbars, live music and theatre the experiences in the Princes Street flagship.:Roof-top bars and theatre part of Johnnie Walker whisky lsquoexperiencersquoThe move will create around  jobs and also see the upgrade of visitor facilities at distilleries which provide the malts for the Johnnie Walker blend.The refurbishment will retain features such as the clock at Binns corner, named after the original storeDiageo said it is investing in revamping its existing  distillery visitor attractions as wellreopening the ldquoiconic distilleries" of Port Ellen and Brora.The design statement, which inlcudes early-stage interior impressions,says the centre offers "a journey through  years of Johnnie Walker and Scotland".It includes an environmental experience that conveys how its distilleries "contribute the essence of their land and water sources"to create the flavour of Scotland.It also includes an interactive exploration of the whisky making process and opportunities to taste.The plan has flexible experiential spaces host dferent activations, including Fringe and other festival events, guest speakers and artists, and pop up installations from immersive innovators and cultural influencers.The roof-top experience will provide visitors with views across the city.Diageos Learning for Le Academy space will also provideflexibility for creative exploration and community programmes.Theprogrammewhich creates training and employment opportunities in the hospitality industry for unemployed people, and works to improve hospitality standards and promotes the responsible serving and consumption of alcohol.Diageo is investing over poundmin total in Scotch whisky experiences in Scotland. As well as the poundm for Edinburgh location and the transformation of its existing  distillery visitor attractions, afurtherpoundm investment will go to reopen Port Ellen and Brora distillers.

title: unspun-the-political-diary
story: FORMER Labour MSP Lesley Brennan was very taken with a Financial Times article this week called ldquoWhy do so many incompetent men win at work . She even posted a link on her Facebook page with aquote from the author. Why the interest in duff blokes  Wersquove no idea. But by pure coincidence, Ms Brennan is chief of staff to Richard Leonard.SNP opposition councillors in North Lanarkshire were mad keen to oppose Labourrsquos budget on the authority, even producing a video featuring new business manager Jordan Linden bragging about their intent. Alas, Cllr Lindenrsquos first big test as whip saw one of his own councillors skip the crucial vote. Remarkably, the absentee was the previous whip, Allan Stubbs. It seems Cllr Linden has inherited all his, er, unique talents.JAMES Kelly suffered another blow this week. For once, it wasnrsquot to his reputation as Scottish Labour finance spokesman. Instead, he lost trusted staffer Kenneth Watt, who has a new job at Oxfam. As one Holyrood wag put it, hersquos going from one charity case to another.SO where was Mr Stubbs when his colleagues were voting  Our mole reports lsquoStumblesrsquo, a self-styled former ldquosecurity consultant, was training for a new gig as a civilian police worker. As he already works for local MSP Fulton MacGregor, questions are now being asked about how many second jobs the councillorrsquos constituents will tolerate.STUMBLES also got it raw at Wednesdayrsquos meeting of the Coatbridge  Chryston SNP branch, we hear. The outfit is synonymous with infighting, even spawning a recent Court of Session defamation action. When Mr Stubbs suggested the convener should quit, activists said he should go instead for admitting in court he may have called a colleague a ldquotwisted bitch. At which the standard pandemonium broke out. You canrsquot buy respect like that.UBIQUITOUS LibDem Alex Cole-Hamilton likes to pose as a chummy, bloke-of-the-people. But is it an act  He was overheard in the Holyrood canteen saying he was feeling ldquoout there over his menu choice. For the first time in his  years, the Edinburgh Western MSP had deigned to eat - gasp! - a pie, chips and beans. His body survived the encounter. We can only pray the psychological wounds heal soon.EVERYONE knows Yessers love a good flag, preferablyitrsquos a Catalan one being waved at random by two men and a dog outside Holyrood. But Scottish Labour also has the bug. Until recently, their parliamentary corridor featured a giant Palestinian flag in Pauline McNeillrsquos room. Now Kezia Dugdale has planted a whopping EU flag in her office. Itrsquos certainly raised eyebrows - everyone assumed Kez would be rallying round the TIG standard.

title: herald-diary-who-wants-a-mini-metro-nowadays
story: THE mixed reception to the BBCs new Scottish channel reminds us of TV stories in the Diary over the years including Glen Michael, who hosted Cartoon Cavalcade on the telly for years, being stopped in the street by an -year-old fan who showed him a cartoon hed drawn of his favourite animated character, Wile E Coyote. Glen dutully looked at it and noticed the boy had drawn the coyote actually catching hold of his nemesis the Roadrunner. What really caught Glens eye was the boys caption which read, "Beep-beep now, ya b******.Whats the score VETERAN newsreader Mary Marquis was one of the most poised and professional presenters on BBC Scotland. But even Mary once admitted that the first time she was handed the football results to read out, she simply read down the first column, rather than across the way. Said Mary: "Till then, I hadnt realised how passionate Scottish football fans are, and I learned a lot of new words when the complaints came in."Hot stuffTHE Rev Eric Hudson, who was involved in religious broadcasting, once told us that they were approached at a TV drinks reception by the late great Chic Murray who offered to appear on the religious slot Late Call with the well-known minister the Rev James Currie. A bit puzzled they asked why, and he replied: "Because you could call it ChicnCurrie.A bit sketchyA READER once claimed that he was in a pub in Glasgows east end where the discussion turned to TV celebrities, and a local chipped in with: "I was on the telly once."Well, not me exactly, but an artists sketch of me.What a cardALL these channels you can now get can be a bit confusing. A reader visited his elderly parents in Dunblane when they were watching the old Bruce Forsyth gameshow Play Your Cards Right on the TV station Gold. After a while his dad remarked: "The prizes are going right downhill! Who wants a Mininowadays "And a Bearsden reader says all the new channels change how you look at things. He said he received an invitation to a wedding that said "+" and for a moment he thought he had to arrive an hour after the other guests.Milked itMANY excuses have been made for not having a TV licence. A resident in Stirling once explained: "Guy from the TV licensing chapped my uncles pals door who told him he didny have a telly, and the guy was like, Youve got an aerial on your roof."He replied: Ive got a pint of milk in the fridge ndash disnae mean Ive got a coo out the back and shut the door.Bit of a tubeWE once overheard a group of students discussing the virtues of buying a high-definition television screen. "My mum came round to the flat and turned our ordinary TV into a high definition one," declared one of them.When asked how she managed that, he told his pals: "She ran a duster over it.Aerial viewA GLASGOW reader told us he heard a woman on the bus into town tell her pal: "My boyfriends that thick that when he saw on my portable TV the sign Built in Antenna he said he didnt know where that was.

title: one-in-four-ready-to-consider-voting-for-independent-group-of-mps
story: Less than a fortnight after the  pro-Remain MPs came together, a poll for the Politico website suggested they were already posing a threat to the political establishment.The eight former Labour MPs and three former Tories hope to become a party, but probably not before Mayrsquos council elections in England.Most of the former Labour members resigned on February  in protest over Jeremy Corbynrsquos dithering on Brexit and anti-Semitism within the party, while the Tories followed two days later in protest at Theresa Mayrsquos handling of Brexit.The survey findings emerged as former Labour MP Chuka Umunna was announced at the ldquogroup spokesman for TIG.In a sign the new formation expects more disaffections, former Tory MP Sarah Wollaston was given responsibility for ldquonew colleagues.Former Tory Anna Soubry takes on the Brexit brief, and former Labour MPs Luciana Berger and Chris Leslie will cover the Home Affairs and Treasury portfolios respectively.The poll of more than  people by Hanbury Strategy found  per cent of LibDem voters would consider voting TIGthey were a party, while only % said it was unlikely.Almost a thirdof Labour supporters also said they might back the new group, compared to % who said they were unlikely to do so.However just % of Tory voters were ready to consider TIG, compared to % opposed.Support for TIG was generally highest among younger voters, and lowest among the elderly.The results will be a particular blow to the LibDems, whose overtures to the TIG have been rebuffed as the group sees them as tainted by their - Coalition with the Tories.The TIGrsquos aim is not to be in a formal a pact with Sir Vince Cablersquos party but to become a new home for ldquoprogressive voters and activists.Mr Umunna, who is expected to use an upcoming speech to flesh out the grouprsquos goals and principles, said: ldquoOur team is erse and drawn from dferent backgrounds, including a former teacher, social worker, lecturer, entrepreneur, solicitor and GP.ldquoWe intend to draw on all the talents and experiences of our group, as we seek to change politics and give the British people a proper alternative to the broken politics being offered by the main political parties.ldquoWe are not a political party and therefore do not have a leader, but the roles and responsibilities we have assigned recognise that all the members of our group have the right to be heard and a responsibility to provide leadership.After suspending Corbynite MP Chris Williams on Wednesday for saying the party had been ldquotoo apologetic on anti-Semitism, Labour is facing another row on this subject.Diane Abbottrsquos constituency party in Hackney called for deselection moves to be instigated against MPs who speak out on anti-Semitism.ldquoIt is unacceptable to allow our representatives to slander the party and its members whilst we put them into office, the motion said.Walthamstow MP Stella Creasy said the motion was ldquodisgraceful and called on Labourrsquos general secretary Jennie Formby to ldquoinvestigate for the sake of all.

title: farm-holidays-could-reap-rich-harvest
story: But now two students are banking on tourists turning their backs on immaculate city breaks and scenic coach trips, by offering them the chance to get their hands dirty down on the farm.Agritourism - where people stay on farms and learn about country le - is big business in the rest of the world and business school scholars George Benson and Mats Zachariassen think its time Scotland got a share of the market.They are aiming to revolutionise the sector by developing a new website which links holidaymakers to farmers offering breaks on their land, and are hoping to convince backers theres fertile ground for the idea.George Benson, left, and Mats ZachariassenGeorge Benson and Mats Zachariassen, who are both studying for a MBA with Stirling Universitys Management School, devised the idea after attending a workshop run by the Scottish Institute for Enterprise . They have now entered their plan into SIErsquos national student entrepreneur competition, lsquoFresh Ideasrsquo.:Tips for a Successful Family HolidayMr Benson, who is originally from Ghana, said: ldquoAgritourism is currently a really niche market in Scotland. Not many agriculture businesses are aware of the potential revenue that could be generated by hosting tourists and those who do provide holiday experiences donrsquot advertise well. As a holidaymaker, it isnrsquot easy to find and book a stay or working holiday on a Scottish farm.ldquoOur website lsquoTour My Farm Experiencesrsquo aims to change that by providing a central  linking farm hosts and experience providers across Scotland with consumers, for the first time.Agritourism is a trend currently booming where in Europe, with Italy boasting , registered farms and an estimated value of euro.billion .By encouraging more agritourists, bookings through the new website could also provide a further boost to Scotlandrsquos already famous food and drink industry.Research by VisitBritain and the Office for National Statistics found that  per cent of visitors to Scotland buy food or drink to take home with them, and VisitScotlandrsquos ldquoScotland Visitor Survey found almost half wanted to try local food while on holiday.:Premier Inn hotel chain to double in size#Holidaying on a farm takes many forms. Tourists could simply find places where the daily le of the agricultural sector goes on around them, without getting involved.Or they could find farms which off full working holidays, teaching tourists about how to feed animals, harvest crops and prepare dairy products.The US has seen a boom in dude ranches, where city dwellers get to shed their business attire for a week and become cowboys and girls, taking part in cattle drives.In Europe tourists can go grape-picking in Italy, brew beer on farms in Latvia and help grow and grow and pick pumpkins in Switzerland.Turkey also enjoys a growing agritourism scene, centred around le in rural villages.Mr Zachariassen added: ldquoThere is a huge trend around sustainability and provenance - knowing where food comes from and how it ends up on our plate. Food and drink is already a vital part of the overall tourism product in Scotland and, by making it easier for visitors to enjoy an agriculture-themed holiday, there could be an added boost for both sectors.Impressing judges with their simple but potentially lucrative business plan, the pair made it through to the second round of the SIE contest and now have the opportunity to win up to pound, of start-up funding. They are the first University of Stirling students to reach this stage.Mr Benson hopes they prove successful and can push on with their business idea. He said: ldquoWersquore hoping to win the competition and use the funding to officially launch the .:Profits drop at InterContinental Hotels but revenue risesldquoFailing that, wersquoll be on the hunt for investors as we really believe in this business. It could easily be expanded to cover the whole of the UK, Europe and the rest of the world, revolutionising agritourism, much like Airbnb has done for short-term stays.Professor George Burt, Director of MBA at the Stirling Management School, said: ldquoFrom day one, our students are encouraged to be open to new ideas, think laterally and act like an entrepreneur.ldquoI am absolutely delighted for George and Mats, who had never met prior to joining the Stirling MBA, and I am confident they will be successful.

title: louella-fletcher-michie-trial-taggart-star-and-family-offer-agonising-witness-statements
story: Not even the knowledge that Ceon Broughton ndash the drug-dealing ex-boyfriend found guilty of being responsible for her manslaughter ndash was starting eight years behind bars could stave off their pain.The -year-old Londoner had ldquobumped up her dose of the hallucinogenic drug -CP. He was also found guilty at Winchester Crown Court three days ago of supplying Miss Fletcher-Michie with the drug before her death at the Bestival music festival in September . He had previously pled guilty to two other charges of supplying drugs to Miss Fletcher-Michie at Glastonbury festival in June .He had tried to wriggle out of the responsibility for his actions. Tried to justy videoing her as she died, her desperate family on the phone begging him to help her.Her father was forced to listen to it all. And yesterday a crushed Holby City actor John Michie, famed for Taggart and Coronation Street too, read his victim impact statement to the court with the conviction no script could ever convey.ldquoI wake up every morning to face le starting again without Louella, our daughter, our sister, our friend, our family ndash now broken, he choked. ldquoAnd for what  It makes no sense ndash our beautul Louella should still be with us on any measure of humanity.ldquoNo more yoga with my daughter, no more running around the outside of the Arsenal stadium with my daughter, no more family fun and laughter with my daughter.ldquoHer le cut cruelly short. Our lives forever diminished.ldquoAsk anyone of the hundreds of people of all creeds and colours from every section of society who were at Louellarsquos celebration of le and they will tell you what a happy and inclusive family we were.ldquoA family who welcomed all Louellarsquos friends into our house with open arms. Her friends always came to her for advice, she was wise beyond her years and trusting, too trusting, it seems.ldquoLosing Louella has made me want to move away from our home where she was born, away from the pain of passing her room, away from the memories of her dancing and laughing in the kitchen or fooling around in the garden, away from her beloved Holloway.ldquoAway from the gut-wrenching pain that those who have lost a child or loved one will understand.ldquoMyself, Daisy and Sam have all had to turn down work because of this trial. A trial where we have been subjected to the horrible truth of Louellarsquos lonely death.ldquoAnd subjected to the tears and anguish of hard-working people, brave enough to stand witness, worrying that they could have done more for Louella.ldquoBut they, the judge and jury, the CPS and their legal team, the police and expert witnesses have all done something for Louella.ldquoThey have revealed the truth and disseminated the lies in front of our eyes for all to see.ldquoI go to bed every night with the trauma of Louella crying out to her mum and dad, her brother and sister to help her, but there was only ever one person who could have helped.Miss Fletcher-Michiersquos father, mother, Carol, and sister, Daisy, also read statements. Daisy said: ldquoI feel like Irsquove lost my parents and my brother too, not just Louella. Seeing everyone you love shatter to pieces, everyone who would usually comfort and support you in times of need, all in the same state as you, heartbroken and traumatised..ldquoI couldnrsquot be alone or get to sleep at night for months. I had constant images in my head and would act out how I imagined everything unfolded on the day, constantly.ldquoI really canrsquot see a positive future, where pain isnrsquot clouding over us all. Louella will be painfully missed every single day.ldquoEvery single day I try to understand why Ceon didnrsquot help Louella, the hours that passed with her getting progressively worse, even having spoken to him on the phone myself and begging him to get her to a medical tent.ldquoWhy didnrsquot he  What was he doing all that time  I constantly question all this but I know Irsquoll never have the answers.ldquoOur lives have been torn apart by the actions of someone who was supposed to have loved Louella, the most-loved person I know.Carol Fletcher-Michie, a former dancer with Hot Gossip, said: ldquoHaving to learn to live with this for the rest of our lives, itrsquos thrown everything I believe in le into question.She added of the defendant: ldquoWe do not think Ceon is evil, he was stupid, massively selfish and he lied.Sentencing Broughton, the judge Mr Justice Goose told him: ldquoYou were only concerned for yourself.The prosecution claimed during the trial that Broughton had failed to take ldquoreasonable steps to seek medical help for Miss Fletcher-Michie.The jury was shown videos taken by the defendant as her condition worsened ndash and possibly after she had died ndash after she had taken a ldquolarge dose of the psychedelic drug on the afternoon of September .In clips shown to the court, Miss Fletcher-Michie repeatedly shouts at Broughton to telephone her mother.Her mother eventually contacted Broughton at .pm and heard her daughter ldquoscreeching before she rushed with her husband to the festival site in a bid to find her.Prosecutor William Mousley QC said Broughton did not get help because he was handed a suspended jail term one month earlier and feared the consequences.Stephen Kamlish QC read a statement from Broughton saying: ldquoSorry I didnrsquot do more to save Louella, sorry for the suffering I caused to everyone who loved Louella.ldquoI want to make things right.

title: schools-need-to-be-a-safe-last-bastion-as-social-media-stress-rises
story: Researchers at Michigan State University found a connection between high social media use and the risky decision making commonly found in other types of addiction.Academics said it also had the potential to cause long-term harm to emotions, behaviour and relationships.Such findings are of concern to everyone who uses social media, but there is particular alarm for families with children who have spent almost their entire lives with a smartphone in hand.According to another recent survey more than a third of young Scots say they felt pressure to live up to the unrealistic expectations of le portrayed on social media.Larry Flanagan, general secretary of the Educational Institute of Scotland , has now called for schools to become ldquosafe bastions against the rising tide of gaming and social media.But he also told an audience of headteachers and deputy heads who are members of the EIS that key subjects such as music, art and drama which could equip pupils with the skills they were missing out on were being squeezed out of the curriculum.He told the conference in Edinburgh: ldquoNeuroscientists tell us that there is an impact of social media and gaming on the way the brain works and for the younger generation that is something that they have experienced nearly all of their lives.ldquoIt is creating increasing isolation and increasing stress for a signicant number of young people and that alternative reality will have ramications for society down the line.ldquoI think schools have to be a safe bastion where social media, while it is part of the pupilrsquos lives, is not part of the school le, so they interact with other pupils, get involved in art, drama and music and have real le experiences in contrast to how they live outside of school.Mr Flanagan praised schools that banned phones for a day to give pupils a ldquodetox from the world of social media.However, he warned that many of the subjects which would prepare pupils best for the world were getting squeezed out through a combination of budget cuts and an over focus on literacy and numeracy and qualications prized by universities.ldquoThe Curriculum for Excellence was supposed to nurture creativity and cultural heritage and engagement, but it is just getting squeezed out, he said.Eileen Prior, executive director of parent body Connect, backed the call.She said: ldquoSchools offer children really valuable face-to-face experiences and opportunities at a time when pupilrsquos lives are increasingly online.ldquoAccess to books and to expressive arts subjects such as art, music and drama are all really important to children and young peoplersquos confidence and wellbeing. We remain concerned that these experiences and opportunities are narrowing in schools.Joanna Murphy, chairwoman of the National Parent Forum for Scotland, said families valued the ldquohuman aspect of formal schooling.She said: ldquoCommunication is key in all human dynamics and canrsquot be replaced by digital means.ldquoSubjects like drama and art are valuable as pupils invest emotionally in them and foster transferable skills useful for their le ahead.ldquoSchools canrsquot replace the family home, but can and should be a refuge from an ever more fast paced world.Dorothy MacGinty, head of Kilgraston, an independent school for girls in Bridge of Earn, near Perth, said a decision to ban mobile phones last year was reaping rewards.She said: ldquoLessons are more interactive, concentration is better and pupils are more engaged in assemblies and particularly co-curricular activities.ldquoIt is vital that schools push activities which deliberately develop these soft skills such as team building, sport, drama and music which all develop critical thinking and self-confidence.ldquoIf schools are to properly educate young people to become the successful and effective members of society they are capable of becoming, a healthy balance of screen time and activity which nurtures soft skills is essential.Speaking to the EIS conference, John Swinney, the Education Secretary, said the new curriculum would only fully deliver for pupils when schools embraced the new powers he wanted to give them.He said: ldquoI am fully behind the Curriculum for Excellence, but it will only reach its full potential and have the impact we believe it can have on the young people of Scotlandit is able to be delivered by a profession that is confident in itself and is creative about how it takes forward that approach.ldquoThat is why our education reforms are designed to put the power to change lives directly in the hands of those with the expertise and insight to target resources in the most valuable way.ldquoIt is a vision that requires the Scottish Government, local government and teachers to work together with a range of partners to drive improvement.

title: concorde-fans-celebrate-50th-birthday
story: But from the moment Concordersquos famous drooped nose rose gracefully from the runway at Toulouse in the south of France and the first prototype took off for a -minute flight, aviation merged with national pride, technology with style and an icon was born.Today aviation fans are expected to gather at locations round the country ndash including Scotlandrsquos National Museum of Flight at East Fortune in East Lothian, where G-BOAArsquos once roaring engines rest in eternal peace ndash to celebrate  years since Concorde took to the skies.ldquoIt is our main attraction, and what brings people here, says Ian Brown, assistant curator of aviation at the East Lothian museum.ldquoVisitors come through the hangar doors and see her nose just lsquohangingrsquo in the air. Irsquove watched their jaws drop as they walk in.Born out of a joint Anglo-French project, Concordersquos maiden flight success was savoured as a moment of intense national pride.Most impressive of all was its speed. A cruising velocity of twice the speed of sound, or mph, allowed it to cover a mile in just . seconds.The epitome of cutting-edge technology of its time, Scots aviation fans can at least claim Concordersquos distinctive swept-back super-slim delta wings as their own.Designed under the leadership of Penicuik-born Sir James Hamilton, they were highly complex with a twist and drop design designed to cope with extreme speed.Hamilton left the Concorde project in , by which time the brave test pilots like fellow Scot, Ayr-born John Cochrane had pushed the craft to her limits.He was at the controls when Concorde blasted through the sound barrier for the first time in , and was on the operational flight when the it reached its highest speed of Mach . and an altitude of ,ft, and achieved the Atlantic speed record from take-off to touchdown in .Cochrane was handed overall responsibility for the engine intake systems ndash a task that involved highpressure flying in which he pushed the aircraft to its technical extremes.Many of what must have been adrenalin-fuelled, near deathdefying test flights took place over the west coast of Scotland.ldquoA lot of these flights were out of Prestwick, which was used as a training base and where pilots would take off and fly for a bit before landing, explains Brown.ldquoBecause of the sonic boom, there were lots of trials and flights, many up and down the west coast of the UK, before she received her certicates.Fty sonic boom test flights took place over three years from .People living along the coast and even in Dublin and Glasgow, were warned to be prepared for the sudden lsquobangrsquo as the aircraft sped by.Incredible as it may seem today, Concordersquos development began just  years after the Second World War had ended, and when Glasgow Corporation trams still rattled through the cityrsquos streets.Throughout her letime, British Airways Concorde fleet would go on to make just under , flights and carry more than .m passengers on the supersonic flight of their lives.Exclusive, fast and unique, it attracted a well-heeled fan base, with regular passengers including Joan Collins, Sir Paul McCartney and Diana, Princess of Wales.Travelling on Concorde became an experience in itself, with its up to  passengers speaking of the ldquokick in the back as the aircraft took off and the rising heat as it powered across the Atlantic.Jock Lowe, the longest serving Concorde pilot, said flying the aircraft was ldquolike driving a sports car compared with a normal car.While BArsquos Concorde fleet regularly ploughed a route ,ft above the ground between London and New York, short day trips from Edinburgh around the Bay of Biscay and back gave lsquoordinaryrsquo passengers the supersonic experience without the eye-watering pound, cost of a transatlantic ticket.ldquoTravel agents like Bennettrsquos in Musselburgh sold tickets, and included with the flight details was a car sticker to put in the window because there would be so many people at the airport just to see Concorde that passengers would be at risk of missing the flight.Concorde was retired from service in October , with British Airways and Air France blaming a downturn in passenger numbers and rising maintenance costs.It also came after an Air France Concorde crashed minutes following take-off from Paris in July , killing all  people on board and four on the ground.Aviation analyst John Strickland does not believe another large-scale version will be developed while passengers prioritise low fares above speed.ldquoIf you cut the time it takes to fly to Australia in half, there would be a level of interest, he said.ldquoBut what would people be willing to pay, relative to the price of such an aircraft and the investment required to make it Meanwhile, for museum visitors there is likely to be a touch of sadness at her early demise.ldquo  was a big issue: no-one wanted to fly to America, and Air Francersquos Paris to New York route was losing money, says Brown.ldquoYet she could have flown for another ten years.

title: what-the-f-are-you-doing-im-one-of-you-brendan-rodgers-responds-to-celtic-fans-flak
story: Rodgers has been severely criticised by many fans for leaving the Parkhead club, who are bidding to win a historic treble treble, before the end of the season.Members of the ultra group The Green Brigade unfurled banners that described him as ldquoa fraud at their Ladbrokes Premiership game against Hearts on Wednesday night.And the Glasgow club described a video that showed fans singing vile chants about the Northern Irishman in a pub in Edinburgh before the match as ldquopathetic and disgusting.Speaking publicly for the first time since making the move to the East Midlands, Rodgers admitted he was aware of the backlash.However, he defended both his actions and his record during his  months in Scotland and described the abuse as ldquosad."Someone showed me the banner when I was at the Leicester Under- game, he said. ldquoOf course, it takes you aback a wee bit. But the supporters are hurting and I understand that.ldquoIts a shame, of course, because from the moment I walked into Celtic I gave my le to the club. I put everything into the training and preparation of the team. A lot of the people wouldnt know that."I havent seen the video, but I had heard there was something. I dont want that to be my final feeling of being at Celtic, especially when its your own."I dont want that to be the final measure of my work there. I gave much more than that.ldquoSo from the banner and the song  To be fair, like I said, I havenrsquot seen the stuff. Thatrsquos sad really. I can only put it down to hurt.ldquoI tend to focus more on the good side. Like I said, supporters will hurt and I get that. I understand that. Thatrsquos why Irsquoll never come out and kill them.Asked what he would say to the supporters who have pilloried him, Rodgers said: ldquoWhat the f*** are you doing  Bloody hell, Irsquom one of you. Okay, I made a career decision. It doesnrsquot make me any less of a Celt.ldquoIrsquom someone who turned up at half seven every morning of his le, was in there until all hours of the night, took over  games a season, preparing a team, changing a culture and a standard at a club, filling the support again.ldquoI tend to focus more on the good side. Like I said, supporters will hurt and I get that. I understand that. Thatrsquos why Irsquoll never come out and kill them.

title: tom-gordon-snps-currency-plan-may-please-members-but-not-voters
story: As shersquos been promising an update ldquoin a few weeks for almost half a year, that may be some time.But conference abhors a vacuum, so her SNP deputy Keith Brown has ridden to the rescue this weekend with a suspiciously fuzzy plan on a new currency after independence.If it was serious, it would be pitched at the electorate. It isnrsquot. Itrsquos pitched at an internal audience.In particular, itrsquos pitched at those many SNP members who are suspicious of the leadershiprsquos Growth Commission, the hair-shirt economic blueprint for an independent Scotland written by former MSP turned corporate lobbyist Andrew Wilson.A heresy against the  White Paper, the Commissionrsquos report recommended spending Decade One after a Yes vote driving down debt and keeping a tight grip on public spending. It also backed keeping the pound ndash at least for now.Ms Sturgeon declared herself delighted, the membership less so. Besides the whf of austerity, there was that plan to keep sterling and UK monetary policies. Former SNP MPs such as George Kerevan politely but firmly laid into it.After hosting a series of National Assemblies to hear the views of SNP members, Mr Brown will put a motion to Aprilrsquos conference backing most of the Commissionrsquos  recommendations, but with a more gung-ho line on currency.Writing for the home crowd in The National yesterday, Mr Brown said: ldquoWe will propose that it should now be party policy that an SNP government in an independent Scotland would establish an independent currency. So far, so clear. But then the fog descends.ldquoOf course, until that can be done safely and securely, our currency would continue to be the pound sterling. It must be done at the right time, in a way that affords necessary protection for our nationrsquos economy and for peoplersquos personal finances.ldquoThe aim of an SNP government would be to complete preparations in time for the newly independent Scottish Parliament, informed by assessments and information from the Central Bank, to take a decision on establishing a new currency by the end of its first term.ldquoThis will ensure that the use of sterling is not an open-ended commitment ndash an issue raised at the National Assemblies.The language is new. But at best, the leadership has moved from agnosticism on a new currency to a highly caveated inclination. Yet something that heavily caveated isnrsquot really a belief in anything. Itrsquos a fudge. Itrsquos also a muddle.For example, Mr Brown seems to suggest evidence and economics would count, but also that Holyrood would decide to back a currency on a set timetable regardless.A politically brave idea, as it would make the following election a referendum on whether to follow through with that decision.Mr Brown also reminds me of someone daydreaming about how theyrsquoll spend their lottery millions before theyrsquove even bought a ticket. It may be enjoyable, but therersquos the small matter of winning first. It was noticeable he didnrsquot offer a timetable on actually securing independence.The audience for this mush is clear from the last line, where he says activists at the partyrsquos National Assemblies didnrsquot like the idea of an open-ended commitment to sterling.They must be a conspiratorial lot. The Growth Commission never made an open-ended commitment to sterling. It said it should be used until something  made more sense, as did the SNP Governmentrsquos Fiscal Commission before the  referendum. Both said sterling was best initially because the UK and Scottish economies were so aligned.But both were open to a new currencythe economies erged. The Commission proposed six tests on credibility, markets, debt, trade, reserves , and public appetite. Explaining the process to voters before a referendum was an ldquoabsolutely necessity, it said. Both were also clear context was all. There was no dogmatism about having or not having a new Scottish currency. It all came down to the circumstances. They definitely did not say, lsquoLetrsquos do this in the first term of an independent parliament to keep the troops happy.rsquoBut it seems National Assembly-goers live in dread of an indefinite backstop on the currency, and want to put a time limit on it, whether itrsquos rational or not. How very ERG-like.I suspect that, behind the fudge, the SNP hierarchy is keeping faith with the Growth Commission, because it sees sense in it, while talking more warmly about a new currency to molly the members.This could backfire on several fronts. The members could see straight through it and get more disgruntled. It was interesting how much scepticism there was from senior SNP figures who want a new currency yesterday. The leadership is not trusted on this. Even vague talk of a new currency could become a giant bullseye for Unionists, who would use to it attack the SNP as reckless and flaky. The party has, after all, backed the euro, the pound, and now, sort of, a third currency.It does not seem driven by long-term national interest, but by short-term party management. The Tories have their Eurosceptics to placate, the SNP their sterling-sceptics.The key thing is whether it helps the cause. But who does this idea appeal to outside the  per cent Will a mystery currency move a single No voter to Yes  Did people reject independence because the last currency offer wasnrsquot radical enough  Did they object to their wages and pensions staying in sterling  Were they crying out to take a punt on a Scottish pound Mr Brown seems to think so. ldquoI believe this approach will maximize support for an independent Scotland, he wrote yesterday. I believe he may be disappointed.

title: scottish-first-time-buyer-numbers-more-than-double-in-a-decade
story: Figures from the Bank of Scotland show there were, in , compared with , in .First-time buyers were found tomake up around half of all house purchases with a mortgage in Scotland, up from % a decade a go.Ricky Diggins, director at the Bank of Scotland, said: ldquoThere has been steady growth of new buyers coming on to the property ladder in Scotland over the last decade, with the proportion of first-time buyers now representing half of the overall market.ldquoThis is important for the wellbeing of the Scottish property market, and has been helped by factors such as continued low mortgage rates.ldquoWith a much lower deposit required north of the border, first-time buyers in Scotland will have to put down a lot less to get the keys to their first home, especially those in East Ayrshire ndash the UKrsquos most affordable place for first-time buyers.ldquoThose looking for their first place in Edinburgh can expect to pay more than double that.The average deposit put down by a first-time buyer in Scotland was % of the purchase price in , jumping dramatically to % in .In , the average deposit dropped to % of the purchase price, although property prices have continued to increase.The pound, average deposit being put down on a first home in Scotland is just over half of the UK-wide average of pound,.Two-bedroom properties have been the first-time buyerrsquos home of choice in Scotland throughout the past decade, making up more than four in  mortgages for first homes in .

title: thousands-of-air-passengers-misdirected-last-year
story: Carriers and airport operators are responsible for directing travellers on international commercial flights towards immigration desks for passport and security checks.But data obtained by the Press Association shows , arrivals were not presented to Border Force immediately after landing in  ndash an average of around six a day.These incidents are logged as ldquomisdirections.Misdirections are also recorded for cases of ldquoover-screening, when passengers arriving on a domestic or Common Travel Area flight are sent to checkpoints unnecessarily.Last year, there were  people in this bracket.In addition,  crew members incorrectly used clearance facilities reserved for operational staff, meaning they did not present at border control as required.Across the three categories, a total of , iniduals were logged as having been misdirected last year.This was a jump of more than , on the number in  and takes the overall tally in the last six years to nearly ,.The Home Office said misdirected passengers are either ed to border control or retrospectively checked against watch lists.Responding to a Press Association Freedom of Information request, the department refused to provide details of last yearrsquos misdirections.It said disclosing information such as dates, flight carriers and airports is ldquolikely to prejudice the operation of immigration controls.While the circumstances of specic incidents have not been released, Government documents previously stated misdirections usually occur because the wrong doors have been opened at the arrival gate or because the airline or airport operator sent the passenger to the wrong place.Ministers are still weighing up whether to press ahead with plans to impose fines of up to pound, on airlines and airportsthey fail to take all reasonable steps to ensure arriving passengers are correctly directed to border controls.Legislation paving the way for the civil penalty regime was passed in  and a consultation on how it would work closed more than a year ago.But the Home Office said the next steps are ldquoyet to be decided.A spokesman for the department said: ldquoThe security of our border is paramount, which is why % of scheduled passengers are checked when arriving in the UK.ldquoIn the small minority of cases where passengers are misdirected they will either be ed to border control or, where this is not possible, retrospectively checked against a range of security and immigration watch lists.ldquoIt is the responsibility of airlines and airport operators to ensure that passengers are directed through the correct route and Border Force is working closely with these stakeholders to tackle this issue.Airport and airline representative bodies are opposed to the fine proposals.Airlines UK said: ldquoWhilst any occurrence of a misdirected passenger is unacceptable and must be fully investigated, the total number of incidents remains extremely low in proportion to the growing number of passengers using UK airports.ldquoRather than a new civil penalty for airlines ndash which we do not believe would be proportionate, effective or fair ndash the focus must instead be on ensuring effective collaboration between the Home Office and the entire industry -including ground handlers and coach providers ndash at each airport.The Airport Operators Associationsaid airports take their role in maintaining the UKrsquos border security ldquoextremely seriously, and are committed to working with airlines, ground handlers and Border Force to bring down the numbers of misdirected passengers.An AOA spokesman added: ldquoWhen despite our best efforts a rare misdirection does occur, such as when airline crew or staff from a ground-handling company accidentally direct passengers down the wrong corridor, airports use their full resources to recover this incident as quickly as possible.ldquoAs a result of this work, the vast majority of passengers who are initially directed to the wrong part of arrivals are fully recovered and redirected to passport control as appropriate.

demands are holding Northern Ireland to ransom, the DUP is delivering on the demands from ordinary people across every part of Northern Ireland who want to see progress in their schools, roads and hospitals.ldquoSinn Fein may have a list of demands about the Irish language which they need to satisfy a section of their support base, but I have a growing list of demands from all over the country from people who want to see progress in their schools, roads and hospitals.ldquoThose people are nationalists, republicans, unionists and those of no constitutional view.

title: former-workers-launch-legal-action-against-clinical-waste-firm-over-pay
story: Hundreds of workers were laid off after Healthcare Environmental Servicesceased trading in December.Thompsons solicitors said they are launching employment tribunal proceedings on behalf of more than  former staff, some of whom say they are owed up to five monthsrsquo pay.MSPs were told in January of a backlog of between  and  tonnes of clinical waste and  tonnes of anatomical waste at Scottish HES sites in Dundee and Shotts.HES has previously denied claims human body parts were among waste stockpiled at its sites but Environment Agency reports said the company stored remains of NHS patients in un-refrigerated units for more than six months.Thompsons partner David Martyn, who is in charge of the legal action, said: ldquoThe former employees of HES were dismissed without notice in December last year. They have now waited three months for their former employer to do the right thing and pay them the wages, notice pay and holiday pay they are owed.ldquoSome employees are owed up to five monthsrsquo pay and have had to resort to food banks to support their families. The time has now come for us to begin formal legal proceedings to force the company to pay the money the workers are due.HES became embroiled in a clinical waste stockpiling controversy with the NHS in , during which it denied claims human body parts were among items caught up in a backlog at its sites.On Thursday afternoon around  workers staged a protest outside the premises in Shotts calling for their wages to be paid.Greig Drysdale, who worked for HES for six months, said many of his former colleagues are owed thousands of pounds.He said: ldquoPeople are annoyed because thatrsquos three months without getting a wage. There are quite a few still not working although the majority have got jobs.ldquoI was only there for six months but Irsquom entitled to my wages, whether itrsquos six months or six years.Elizabeth Mellon, who worked at HES for  months, said she is owed around pound,.She said: ldquoI hope HES will see that wersquore still angry and upset.ldquoI started working again about five weeks ago and got paid but the wage just went to pay everyone back who had lent me money.Scottish Labour leader Richard Leonard also attended the protest.He said: ldquoItrsquos a question of a fair dayrsquos pay for a fair dayrsquos work but itrsquos also a question of justice. The people that worked here who built this company up have been left abandoned with money owed to them and with lots of questions still unanswered.HES have been asked for a comment.The UK Government Insolvency Service said workerswho have had a contract for more than two years are entitled to redundancy pay.It said it has received  claims for redundancy and has paid out pound, to claimants, with only one claim outstanding.A spokesman said: ldquoHealthcare Environmental Services has not put itself into insolvency so under law the workers cannot claim for wages owed, notice pay or holiday pay at this time.ldquoIf the company puts itself into an insolvency procedure then these payments could be made.Sepa said it is carrying outregular inspections of the sites.A statement posted on the HES website in January said ldquothedirectors and senior managers of HES have fought daily for the survival of the business, while owner Garry Pettigrew said he was still fighting for workers.A Scottish Government spokesman said: ldquoWe have supported affected employees through our Pace initiative and will continue to monitor the situation and provide further support as required.ldquoThe company has claimed that their bank refused to release funds to pay salaries. Minister for Business, Fair Work and Skills Jamie Hepburn attempted to intervene in this situation and contacted Mr Pettigrew to seek his permission for the minister to contact the companyrsquos bank HSBC. Mr Pettigrew refused permission.ldquoIn response to a request from HES former employees, the minister then contacted HSBC directly, who advised they would require Mr Pettigrewrsquos permission to discuss any issues with the minister. Mr Pettigrew once again refused this permission.ldquoWe stand ready and willing to engage with them againthe company requires help in releasing funds to pay staff salaries.

title: large-demonstrations-in-algeria-against-ailing-presidents-rule
story: It was an exceptional popular challenge to the countryrsquos secretive leadership.Protesters surged past a barricade and defied repeated volleys of tear gas fired by police in the march in Algiers.Most marchers were peaceful but a small group throwing stones clashed at the end of the event with police, causing some injuries.Such anti-government protests are unusual in Algeria, where questions are growing about Mr Bouteflikarsquos fitness for office after a  stroke that has left him largely hidden from public.Police helicopters circled overhead as crowds gathered in streets and parks of Algiers after midday Muslim prayer services to join the march.Organisers of the social media-driven movement hope the protest will send a loud signal of public discontent to Algeriarsquos secretive leadership before the April  presidential election.ldquoFor a free and democratic Algeria! shouted some demonstrators, or ldquoNo fth term!The crowd included families with small children and women in headscarves or jeans.Riot police lined key avenues, determined to keep marchers from nearing government buildings.Bursts of tear gas fire punctuated the afternoon, starting soon after crowds started gathering.More and more demonstrators joined in as the group marched along a route parallel to the cityrsquos Mediterranean shore.Police stopped the crowd near the central post office, and the protestersrsquo chants briefly fell silent as they joined together to sing the Algerian national anthem.Then the crowd overwhelmed a police barricade, pushing on toward Martyrsrsquo Square in the historic Casbah neighbourhood.

title: days-out-scotlands-15-most-unusual-museums
story: . The museum tells the story of those who worked in the factory, as well as giving an insight into le in a nuclear power station, with a new exhibit that gives a virtual reality -degree walkthrough of nearby Chapelcross Power Station.. Trying to spot all the buses you remember is a great way to lose an hour or two, with the vehicles kept in immaculate condition thanks to the enthusiastic staff. They can also give you a guided tour and,yoursquore lucky, a ride on one of the buses.. Surgeonsrsquo Hall Museum, EdinburghNicolson Street  Open every day am-pmAdults pound., concessions pound, under-s not advised to attendwww.museum.rcsed.ac.ukNot one to visityou have a weak stomach, Edinburghrsquos Surgeonsrsquo Hall Museum holds one of the largest pathology collections in the UK. Visitors can expect to see a rangeof historical surgical instruments,dental tools and equipment and, moststomach-churning of all, body parts stored in jars.. Glasgow Police MuseumFirst floor of  Bell Street, Merchant City, Glasgow  Open Tuesday am-.pm and Sunday pm-.pm , freewww.policemuseum.org.uk This hidden gem of a museum charts the history of Glasgowrsquos police force ndashthe first in Britain ndash from  to . It may be small but it offers plenty to interest visitors, including unorms, photographs and newspaper clippings that detail crimes that were committed and solved in the city.. Orkney Wireless Museum Junction Road, Kirkwall, OrkneyOpen Monday-Saturday .am-.pm and Sunday .pm-.pm Adults pound, children and concessions poundwww.orkneywirelessmuseum.org.ukThe sheer notion of a ldquowireless is one that is likely to warrant blank expressions from younger generations. But for those who remember the radio in its heyday of cultural and practical importance, this museum will conjure up plenty of fond memories and nostalgia.. Savings Banks Museum, RuthwellRuthwell, Dumfries, Dumfries and GallowayOpen Thursday-Saturday am-pm , freewww.savingsbankmuseumIt might not sound particularly thrilling but this museum tells the le story of the fascinating Henry Duncan, the founder of the savings bank, who was born near Dumfries in . Visitors can learn more about Duncan, and the origins of the bank, as well as admiring the collection of home savings boxes, coins and banknotes from around the world.. Montrose Air Station Heritage CentreWaldron Road, Broomfield, Montrose, Angus Open Saturdays am-pm and Sundays pm-pm Adults pound, concessions pound, children freewww.rafmontrose.org.ukThe first operational military airfield established in the UK, Montrose Air Station played an integral part in the RAFrsquos operations throughout the Second World War. It is staffed by volunteers who ensure that visitors get a sense of le during the war ndash with a s room full of memorabilia, an Anderson air raid shelter and even a room replicating a pilotrsquos bedroom from . There are plenty of planes, both real and replica, with visitors encouraged to interact with any exhibits that donrsquot explicitly say otherwise.Glasgow, Gateway to Scotland: The best Charles Rennie Mackintosh within  minutes. Scotlandrsquos Secret BunkerUnderground Nuclear Command Centre, Crown Buildings, Troywood, St Andrews. Adults pound., children pound.Open every day am-pmwww.secretbunkerHidden under an innocuous farmhouse in the middle of rolling Fe countryside, this museum certainly lives up to its secretive name. The , square feet of underground bunker was intended to host the government during the Cold War in the event of a nuclear catastrophe. The command control centre, dormitories and even chapel that are contained within it demonstrate just how readied the British government was for such a calamity ndash and how only a precious few would have been spared.. Scottish Fisheries Museum, AnstrutherHarbourhead, Anstruther, Fe Open Monday-Saturday am-.pm and Sunday pm-.pmAdults pound, concessions pound, children freewww.scotfishmuseum.orgChildren will love this hands-on museum about the history of the fishing industry, with ldquodo touch signs that encourage you to interact with the exhibits. It highlights the struggles that come with the job, with audio from a trawler skipper, a replica fishermanrsquos cottage and preserved boats that give you a feel for a le spent at sea.. Shetland Textile MuseumBod of Gremista, Gremista Industrial Estate, Lerwick, Shetland Open Tuesday-Saturday pm-pm , entry poundwww.shetlandtextilemuseumThe quality of Shetland wool isworld-renowned and this museum pays homage to knitwear, lace and taatit rugs that are native to the island. Visitors can admire the quality of craftmanship on display, with frequently changing exhibitions and demonstrations that showcase the importance of textiles to this community.. Inveraray Jail, Argyll Church Square, Inveraray, ArgyllOpen every day am-pmAdults pound., children pound., seniors pound.www.inverarayjailThis th-century jail was used to try, sentence and imprison criminals of the day ndash some as young as seven ndash before it was closed to make way for prisons in larger towns across Scotland. Visitors can view historic torture weapons, walk around the cramped cells of the old prison and enter the county courtroom, listening to extracts from trials held there. There is also a ldquomodern-day cell to give a sense of what prison le is like today.Days Out: The best  wintry walks in Scotland
